metadata.titleEn: In-situ measurement data set (2019) of the soil moisture and temperature wireless sensor network within the Shandian River Basin
metadata.description:
This data set contains in-situ measurements of soil moisture, soil temperature and precipitation at 34 stations from a wireless Soil Moisture Network within the ShanDian River basin (referred to as the SMN-SDR hereafter). The coverage of entire network is about 10,000 km2 (115.5-116.5°E, 41.5-42.5°N). The topography of the SMN-SDR is relatively flat, and land surfaces are typically dominated by grasslands and croplands. A total of 34 stations are set up in the network with three sampling scales including 100 km (large scale), 50 km (medium scale), and 10 km (small scale). The soil moisture sensors used are Decagon 5TM with five measuring depths (3, 5, 10, 20, and 50 cm) installed for each station. Of the 34 station, there are 20 stations equipped with HOBO rain gauges. Undisturbed soil samples at each layer of soil for each station was taken to analyze the gravimetric/volumetric water content, bulk density, and soil texture for a further specific calibration. The power supply is provided by solar panels and all data can be transmitted wirelessly to a server. The sampling interval of the data recording time is 10 (before June 2019) or 15 minutes (after June 2019).
This network can improve the comprehensive observation capabilities of key water cycle parameters in the ShanDian River basin and provide long-term ground reference data for satellite- and model-based soil moisture products.
metadata.instructions:
File naming: The in-situ measurement data set of the SMN-SDR is stored in csv format, and the file name is: "ShandianRiver_XY_5TM/HOBO_SM/TS/PP_xxcm_YYYY-MM-DD_YYYY-MM-DD.csv".
where, X represents the sampling scales, usually “L” (100km) or “M” (50km) or “S” (10km); Y stands for site number; 5TM/HOBO stands for sensor type, for example, the sensor for soil moisture and soil temperature data is 5TM, and the sensor for precipitation observation is HOBO; SM/TS/PP represents the type of in-situ data, SM is soil moisture, TS is soil temperature, and PP is precipitation; xxcm represents the detection depth, usually "03cm", "05cm", "10cm", "20cm", "50cm". Note that when the measurement data is precipitation, xxcm does not display. YYYY-MM-DD_YYYY-MM-DD represents the start and end time of the in-situ data.
Data reading method: The data set can be directly opened with a text program (such as notepad or excel).

background: Soil moisture is a key element of the terrestrial water cycle, controlling various hydrological, ecological, and biogeochemical processes. The acquisition of accurate surface soil moisture data is critical for many applications, including drought monitoring, crop yield estimation, flood prediction, and heat-wave forecasting. Considering the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, point-scale in situ measurements can only obtain precise information over a very small area. Accordingly, in situ measurements are usually too sparse to specifically describe the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales. To meet research and application needs, various global-scale soil moisture products have been developed, which can be roughly divided into the following three major groups: (1) Remotely sensed soil moisture directly retrieved from active/passive satellite microwave observations. Microwave remote sensing, especially passive microwave, has become an effective way to estimate soil moisture at large scales due to its strong sensitivity to soil moisture, as well as the advantages of short-term access and all-weather monitoring. Several satellite platforms carrying passive/active microwave sensors have been successfully operated for the past decades, including (but not limited to) low-frequency passive microwave sensors such as SMOS (Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity) and SMAP (Soil Moisture Active Passive), high-frequency passive microwave sensors such as AMSR2 (Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer-2) and Chinese Fengyun series satellites, and active microwave sensors such as ASCAT (the Advanced Scatterometer) and Sentinel-1. Based on the observed passive (brightness temperature, TB) and/or active (backscatter coefficient) microwave signals, these platforms have developed corresponding retrieval algorithms and released soil moisture products to the public. (2) Merged soil moisture products estimated by blending multiple separately released microwave remotely sensed products. The most typical case is the CCI (Climate Change Initiative) project. (3) Model-derived soil moisture, including (but not limited to) NASA’s Global Land Data Assimilation System (GLDAS), NASA’s Modern-Era Retrospective analysis for Research and Applications (MERRA), and the European Center for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) Land Surface Reanalysis v5-Land (ERA5-Land) soil moisture products. There are different retrieval procedures, design accuracy, input datasets, and spatial-temporal resolution between the different soil moisture products, with their accuracy affected by different factors. For instance, the quality of satellite-based soil moisture products is hindered by retrieval algorithms, microwave instrument characteristics, topography, climate, and land cover conditions, while the model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors are the main factors for the uncertainty of model-based products. The validation of soil moisture products is commonly based on comparison with reference data, which is assumed to be a good representation of ground truth, aiming to calculate their systematic and random errors and obtain quantitative statistics about the quality of soil moisture products. The random error variance of three collocated datasets can be estimated through triple collocation analysis (TCA), without the need for a single high-quality reference data, which is why TCA has been widely used in soil moisture validation studies. Inter-comparison between soil moisture products and dense in situ measurements (namely fiducial reference data or ground-truth) is currently the primary approach used to assess soil moisture products. Several scientific teams have established dedicated soil moisture networks, including the SMAP core validation sites and monitoring networks in the Tibetan Plateau.
research objective: This study is the first to use in situ measurements from the SMN-SDR to conduct a comprehensive evaluation of commonly used, multi-source soil moisture products. These results are expected to further promote the improvement of satellite- and model-based soil moisture products.
challenges: Considering the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, point-scale in situ measurements can only obtain precise information over a very small area. Accordingly, in situ measurements are usually too sparse to specifically describe the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales. The quality of satellite-based soil moisture products is hindered by retrieval algorithms, microwave instrument characteristics, topography, climate, and land cover conditions, while the model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors are the main factors for the uncertainty of model-based products. The inevitable differences in spatial-temporal scale, and the construction of a dense network which is labor-intensive (e.g. repeated measuring) and costly, are the main challenges for ground-based evaluation. Although this approach is capable of solving scale issues and achieving a global-scale assessment, it can only provide relative conclusions between different soil moisture products, since these non-fiducial reference data may inherently contain unknown biases and uncertainties. The use of TCA requires some basic assumptions, which are often violated.
methods: In this study, in situ measurements of the SMN-SDR were used to evaluate 24 different soil moisture datasets grouped according to three categories: (1) single-sensor satellite-based products, (2) multi-sensor merged products, and (3) model-based products. Triple collocation analysis (TCA) was applied to all possible triplets to verify the reliability and robustness of the results.
dataset: The SMN-SDR currently consists of 34 stations within an area of ~10,000 km² (115.5 – 116.5°E, 41.5 – 42.5°N). At each station, five Decagon 5TM sensors were installed in a horizontal orientation at different measuring depths (3, 5, 10, 20, and 50-cm) to measure soil moisture and soil temperature. The nominal accuracy (and resolution) of the 5TM sensor are ± 3% m³/m³ (0.0008 m³/m³) for soil moisture and ± 1 K (0.1 K) for soil temperature. A total of 24 near-surface, coarse-resolution soil moisture datasets were used in this study, including 15 based on single-sensor satellite-based products (seven for L-band low-frequency passive microwave observations, seven for C/X-band higher-frequency passive microwave observations, and one for C-band active microwave observation), six based on multi-sensor merged products, and three based on land surface models.
findings: The results reveal that the latest Climate Change Initiative (CCI) -combined product (v06.1, merging extra low-frequency passive microwave data) had the best agreement with in situ measurements from the SMN-SDR, with the lowest ubRMSE (< 0.04 m³/m³) and highest R (> 0.6). Among all single-sensor retrieved soil moisture products, the Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) products performed best in terms of R (> 0.6) and ubRMSE (close to 0.04 m³/m³), with the SMAP-MDCA (Modified Dual Channel Algorithm) being slightly better than the baseline SCA-V (Single Channel Algorithm-Vertical polarization). Importantly, the newly developed SMAP-IB product, which does not use auxiliary data, delivered the best bias statistics and higher VOD values compared with the drier SMAP retrievals, suggesting that the low VOD values (underestimated vegetation effects) may be the major factor causing the dry bias of SMAP products in this study area. It was also found that TCA may systematically overestimate the correlation and underestimate the ubRMSE of soil moisture products as compared with ground-based metrics. Redundant TCA-based metrics from multiple independent triplets could be averaged to increase the accuracy of final TCA estimates.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure soil moisture and temperature in a large-scale wireless sensor network?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of Decagon 5TM sensors, which are installed in a horizontal orientation at different depths (3, 5, 10, 20, and 50 cm) at each station within a network of 34 stations spanning an area of approximately 10,000 km². These sensors measure soil moisture and soil temperature with specific nominal accuracy and resolution.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using in situ measurements for evaluating soil moisture products at large scales?
Example.Answer: A challenge is the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, where point-scale in situ measurements can only obtain precise information over a very small area, making them too sparse to specifically describe the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales. This is compounded by the labor-intensive and costly nature of constructing a dense network for ground-based evaluation.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how different soil moisture datasets are evaluated for accuracy and reliability?
Example.Answer: An example is the use of Triple Collocation Analysis (TCA) to evaluate 24 different soil moisture datasets, grouped into single-sensor satellite-based products, multi-sensor merged products, and model-based products. TCA is applied to all possible triplets to verify the reliability and robustness of the results, allowing for a systematic comparison against in situ measurements.

Definition.Question: What is triple collocation analysis (TCA) and how is it used in soil moisture validation?
Definition.Answer: Triple collocation analysis (TCA) is a statistical method used to estimate the random error variance among three collocated datasets without the need for a single high-quality reference. In soil moisture validation, TCA helps verify the reliability and robustness of different soil moisture products by comparing them with reference data assumed to represent the ground truth, thereby assessing their systematic and random errors.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with in situ soil moisture measurements in terms of spatial-temporal variation?
Definition.Answer: The challenges associated with in situ soil moisture measurements in terms of spatial-temporal variation include the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, which limits the precision of point-scale measurements to very small areas. This limitation makes it difficult to describe the spatial-temporal variation over large scales, and constructing a dense network for ground-based evaluations is labor-intensive and costly.

Comparison.Question: How do in situ measurements from a wireless sensor network compare to satellite-based soil moisture data in terms of spatial coverage and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: In situ measurements from a wireless sensor network provide precise data at specific points with high temporal resolution but cover a smaller area compared to satellite-based data, which offers broader spatial coverage but may have reduced accuracy due to retrieval algorithms and environmental factors.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection methods between single-sensor satellite-based products and multi-sensor merged products for soil moisture estimation?
Comparison.Answer: Single-sensor satellite-based products use data from individual satellite sensors, such as passive or active microwave observations, while multi-sensor merged products blend data from multiple satellite sensors to improve spatial and temporal resolution and accuracy.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges faced in constructing a dense in situ measurement network compare to those encountered when validating satellite-based soil moisture products?
Comparison.Answer: Constructing a dense in situ measurement network is labor-intensive and costly, involving repeated measurements over small areas, whereas validating satellite-based products involves dealing with the intrinsic spatial-temporal scale discrepancies and biases due to retrieval algorithms and environmental conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What potential methodologies can be derived for improving soil moisture product validation using ground-based networks, and what limitations might these methodologies encounter?
Interpretation.Answer: Potential methodologies for improving soil moisture product validation using ground-based networks include the use of triple collocation analysis (TCA) to estimate errors without high-quality reference data and inter-comparison with dense in situ measurements. Limitations may arise from assumptions required by TCA, potential biases in non-fiducial reference data, and the labor-intensive nature of constructing dense networks.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges in obtaining accurate large-scale soil moisture data from in situ measurements in the field of soil moisture monitoring?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in obtaining accurate large-scale soil moisture data from in situ measurements are primarily due to the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, which means that point-scale in situ measurements can only provide precise information over a very small area. Consequently, these measurements are often too sparse to describe the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales effectively.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do satellite-based soil moisture products face accuracy issues, and what factors contribute to these errors?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Satellite-based soil moisture products face accuracy issues due to several factors, including the limitations of retrieval algorithms, the characteristics of microwave instruments, and the influence of topography, climate, and land cover conditions. These factors collectively hinder the quality of the satellite-based soil moisture products.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What leads to the uncertainty in model-based soil moisture products, and how do these factors impact their reliability?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The uncertainty in model-based soil moisture products is primarily caused by factors such as model structure, input parameters, and atmospheric forcing errors. These elements impact the reliability of the products by introducing potential inaccuracies and biases in the soil moisture estimates.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might result from using point-scale in situ measurements to evaluate large-scale soil moisture products?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using point-scale in situ measurements can lead to challenges in accurately describing the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales due to their sparse distribution. These measurements provide precise information over small areas, but their sparseness may cause difficulties when they are used to evaluate large-scale soil moisture products, which can result in a lack of comprehensive validation and potential biases in the products.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing Triple Collocation Analysis (TCA) for soil moisture product validation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying Triple Collocation Analysis (TCA) for soil moisture product validation could systematically overestimate the correlation and underestimate the unbiased root mean square error (ubRMSE) of soil moisture products. This method requires assumptions that may often be violated, and while averaging redundant TCA-based metrics from multiple independent triplets can increase accuracy, it may still only provide relative conclusions between different soil moisture products due to potential inherent biases and uncertainties.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intended outcome of utilizing wireless sensor networks to measure soil moisture and temperature across different spatial scales in a river basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcome is to provide long-term ground reference data for the validation of satellite-retrieved and model-simulated soil moisture products, ensuring their accuracy for various applications like drought monitoring and crop yield estimation.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to calibrate in situ soil moisture measurements with soil samples at various depths?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Calibrating in situ soil moisture measurements with soil samples at various depths is essential for accuracy, allowing for the correction of raw sensor data to account for factors like weight/volume water content, bulk density, and soil texture, which ensures reliable data for validating satellite and model-based soil moisture products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used for calibrating the measurements of soil moisture and temperature collected from wireless sensor networks in large-scale river basins?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To calibrate the measurements of soil moisture and temperature collected from wireless sensor networks, soil samples are periodically collected from each station at various depths and analyzed for weight/volume water content, bulk density, and soil texture. This analysis helps in calibrating the original measurement data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How does the network of wireless sensors ensure data accuracy and consistency across different scales and locations within a large geographical area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The network includes sensors set at various scales (100 km, 50 km, and 10 km) and depths (3, 5, 10, 20, and 50 cm) to ensure comprehensive coverage. Data accuracy and consistency are maintained by using standardized sensors (Decagon 5TM) and calibration through periodic soil sampling and analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are encountered in maintaining a wireless sensor network for soil moisture and temperature monitoring, and what methods are employed to address these challenges?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, cost, and labor-intensive maintenance of the network. To address these, a dense network is constructed, and methods like triple collocation analysis are used for validating and ensuring data reliability, despite the inherent limitations of spatial-temporal scale differences.

Enablement.Question: How does the application of Triple Collocation Analysis (TCA) enhance the validation of soil moisture datasets derived from various sources?
Enablement.Answer: Triple Collocation Analysis (TCA) is applied to all possible triplets of soil moisture datasets to verify the reliability and robustness of the results without needing a single high-quality reference dataset. This approach enables the estimation of random error variance and provides a systematic method for assessing the quality and accuracy of different soil moisture products, including those based on satellite, merged, and model-derived data.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to achieve accurate soil moisture data collection over large scales using point-scale in situ measurements?
Expectation.Answer: Due to the strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture, point-scale in situ measurements can only obtain precise information over very small areas, making them too sparse to specifically describe the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales.

Expectation.Question: Why could the validation of soil moisture products using ground-based networks be considered both essential and problematic?
Expectation.Answer: The validation of soil moisture products is essential because it involves comparison with reference data to calculate systematic and random errors, providing quantitative statistics about the quality of soil moisture products. However, it is problematic because constructing a dense network is labor-intensive and costly, and inevitable differences in spatial-temporal scale further complicate the evaluation.

Expectation.Question: Why might Triple Collocation Analysis (TCA) be an attractive yet complex method for evaluating soil moisture products?
Expectation.Answer: TCA is an attractive method because it allows for estimating the random error variance of datasets without needing a single high-quality reference data. However, it is complex as it requires some basic assumptions, which are often violated, and may systematically overestimate the correlation and underestimate the ubRMSE of soil moisture products compared with ground-based metrics.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are in situ measurements in capturing the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales, given the inherent challenges highlighted in the field?
Judgmental.Answer: In situ measurements are limited in capturing the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales due to their point-scale nature, which provides precise information only over a very small area. The strong spatial heterogeneity of soil moisture and the sparseness of such measurements make it difficult to describe variations comprehensively.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how in situ measurements can adequately represent the spatial-temporal variation of soil moisture over large scales.
Assertion.Answer: In situ measurements, like those from the SMN-SDR, are limited in representing large-scale spatial-temporal variations of soil moisture due to strong spatial heterogeneity and point-scale precision. They are typically too sparse to describe variations over large areas, which is why satellite and model-based products are also used for broader coverage.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why satellite-based soil moisture products have uncertainties despite advanced technology.
Assertion.Answer: Satellite-based soil moisture products face uncertainties due to factors like retrieval algorithms, microwave instrument characteristics, topography, climate, and land cover conditions. These complexities affect the quality and accuracy of the data despite technological advancements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose potential methods to enhance the calibration of soil moisture datasets collected via wireless sensor networks, considering different soil types and environmental conditions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Calibration of soil moisture datasets can be enhanced by periodically collecting and analyzing soil samples to determine characteristics like volumetric water content, bulk density, and soil texture. This data can calibrate the sensor measurements. Additionally, using multi-sensor data fusion techniques and incorporating environmental condition data can improve calibration processes, ensuring datasets account for varying soil types and conditions.
